message: I'd like to be able to evaluate an arbitrary string from a chatroom in my python interpreter without worrying about somebody erasing my hard drive for kicks
[I haven't looked at this code] maybe check this https://github.com/haypo/pysandbox
pypy apparently has a sandboxed mode that I'm looking at
there's no really really easy way of doing it
I know, that's the part I don't want to do :)
but all I really want to support are simple calculations
it's nice that it's supposed to be configurable, so you could enable the bare minimum for what you need, just in case
phew, the error was mundane, the error handling code was busted
@alex didn't bust my chatbot, I just had a simple bug
hmm the while 1 might be an issue, let's see
and this seemed much easier, I had it running in just a few minutes
haha it seems questionable whether I should answer that :)
snow leopard, not the framework python build though
yeah, I'm smart enough to know I'm not smart enough to write that code :)
you could still DoS it with a really high number in that range... I should set a timeout
good recommendation, it seems to work exactly as advertised
and this all running on a mac what version of leopard or snow leopard?
is it the server build of snow leopard?

(I've got some AST filtering code lying around somewhere)
it's supposed to work the same regardless of os
I thought you were running this on a VPS, man you've balls :D
@llimllib sorry can't help myself :), how are you doing the sandboxing?
is the timeout a sandbox feature?
cool, I should place it in a bookmark somewhere
damn, now that I know it's victors thing and not some hack job breaking it would be much harder
@llimllib very few people are, when victor originally mailed the list people found tons of insane ways to break it
ah yes, I remember when victor posted this to python-dev
I think I remember that thread
hmm, although I guess a statement that was eval()ed in a lambda might work?
*shrug* somebody can delete all my TV shows if they bust it
plus whoever busts it will have to do so in public
@alex no worries, it's the first thing I'd do too.
yeah... I tried to build the PyPy one but failed
it's also wrapped in a lambda, so statements won't work
I'm trying out some code to download your pr0n
PyPy, IronPython, and Jython all have them AFAIK
Granted that also interpreted ast trees manually
SandboxError: exit() function blocked by the sandbox
/eval "statements won't work, only expressions, and it's py2.7"
yeah, I can't get the "encodings" module working
thanks, you found a unicode bug for me though
statements won't work, only expressions, and it's py2.7
/eval for x in range(10**100000000000): print x
/eval (x for x in range(20) if x % 2 == 0)
/eval [x for x in range(20) if x % 2 == 0]
/let x = (x for x in range(20) if x % 2 == 0)
/eval locals().update({'var2':(x for x in range(20) if x % 2 == 0)})
That doesn't seems like it would work
@Nettok you'd have to cheat a bit to set a variable; /eval (x for x in range(2) if x % 2 == 0); __result = list(__result)
@italiano40 yeah, I'd rather keep it limited to simple expressions
@Vasil I'll figure out why the timeout's not working
/eval (x for x in range(2) if x % 2 == 0); __result = list(__result)
@llimllib yea i hear you on the simple expressions, and if i get time who knows what will be going on
once it worked, I left it
hmm the timeout should have killed that
it be cool if it save the variable
wait i am looking at the source, and it just keeps getting live.json, there is no streaming api for json in python? @llimllib
@italiano40 tbh, I'm a lazy man and I wrote that loop in <5 minutes
@llimllib i mean there is no way to handle a live polling of a json stream in python, like in java we can use the gson streaming api to read a json file and keep the live polling alive
Well, if you're dead set on wanting to run a restricted python, you could always use RestrictedPython http://pypi.python.org/pypi/RestrictedPython :)

hmm it's not clear what killed the bot there
@holdenweb well, it was a one-request DoS that worked by eval'ing something that swallowed all the computer's memory
@holdenweb yeah, I'm mainly relying on the publicity of convore, the boredom factor, and the complete lack of valuable targets on my TV computer
I have the bot die on receiving a non-200 atm, so it died overnight at some point
@llimllib Could you test DoSing on a local net? S'pose it's still pretty tedious.

Not too much you can do about that. I believe Dr. Cannon concluded that there is only so far you can go by hobbling the virtual machine. Clearly access to "eval()" would be an obvious hole to block, but that's a band-aid.
I removed the babysitting code that fails on any error, but haven't deployed it yet
